misconceptions.name: Grade is hardcoded instead of read from user
misconceptions.description: The program never reads a numeric grade from the keyboard; instead it uses a fixed literal value for the grade, so user input cannot affect the grade calculation as required.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe that using a fixed grade value in the code (e.g., 85) is sufficient for demonstrating the grade logic, rather than reading the grade from the user as specified.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should prompt the user for a grade (e.g., "Enter grade:"), then use a Scanner method such as nextInt() or nextDouble() to read that value from the keyboard and base all subsequent decisions on that input.
symptoms: Program always uses grade = 85 regardless of any user input
No prompt like "Enter grade:" appears in the program
Scanner is only used to read coordinate values, not the grade
misconceptions.root_cause: The student likely reused or focused on example code and did not translate the requirement to read the grade value from the user into their own I/O logic.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Replace the hardcoded grade assignment with a prompt and a Scanner read, e.g., print "Enter grade:" and then call input.nextInt() to store the user's grade in the grade variable.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: High confidence because the only grade value in the code is a literal 85 and there is no input prompt or Scanner call to read a grade.

evidence.note: The grade is set to a fixed literal (85) and is never read from the Scanner, so the program does not accept a grade from the user.
Scanner input is used only for coordinates, not for reading any grade value from the keyboard.

misconceptions.task: Mapping each range to correct letter output
misconceptions.name: Implemented distance calculator instead of grade calculator
misconceptions.description: The program computes and prints the distance between two points instead of mapping a numeric grade (0–100) to a letter grade (A–F) with the specified ranges, so it does not address the required problem at all.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe that writing a distance-between-points program (possibly from another example) is acceptable for this task, or did not fully switch their template to implement the grade calculator logic.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should read a numeric grade, use an if-else chain to test which range (A, B, C, D, F) the grade falls in, and then print the corresponding letter grade such as "Letter grade: B".
symptoms: Program prompts for x1, y1, x2, y2 instead of a single grade value
Output reports the distance between two points, not a letter grade
No conditions covering the full set of ranges A (90–100), B (80–89), C (70–79), D (60–69), F (below 60)
No output line like "Letter grade: X" appears anywhere
misconceptions.root_cause: The student likely reused or copied a distance-formula example and did not replace its logic with the grade-classification algorithm described in the assignment.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Remove or ignore the distance-related code and write a new main that reads a single numeric grade, uses if/else-if conditions to check each range (A, B, C, D, F), and prints the correct letter grade string.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The class name, prompts, and main computation are all about distance; there is no trace of the required grade-to-letter mapping logic.

evidence.note: The entire main method is structured around computing and printing the distance between two points, with no mention of grades or letter-grade output.

misconceptions.name: Completely off-topic code implementation
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a program to calculate the distance between two points instead of implementing the Grade Calculator as required by the problem prompt. The entire submission is irrelevant to the requested task.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to have copied or written code for a different programming problem (Distance Between Points) and submitted it for the Grade Calculator problem.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The student must write code that specifically addresses the requirements of the Grade Calculator problem: reading a single integer grade (0-100) and using conditional logic (if/else if/else) to print the corresponding letter grade.
symptoms: Code reads four double inputs (x1, y1, x2, y2).
Code calculates Euclidean distance.
Code does not read a single integer grade.
Code does not contain if-else logic for grading ranges.
misconceptions.root_cause: Misreading the assignment prompt, submitting the wrong file, or using template code that was intended for a different task.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Review the assignment prompt carefully. Delete/replace the current code with logic that takes a single homework grade as input and uses if/else statements to determine the letter grade (A, B, C, D, F).

evidence.note: The entire main logic pertains to calculating distance, not calculating a letter grade.

misconceptions.task: Correct Boolean ranges for A and B
misconceptions.name: Use of single AND operator (&) in boolean expression
misconceptions.description: The student uses the bitwise AND operator (`&`) instead of the logical conditional AND operator (`&&`) inside a conditional test. While this works for boolean operands in Java, it forces evaluation of both sides of the expression (no short-circuiting) and is generally incorrect practice for logical branching, suggesting a misunderstanding of Java's logical versus bitwise operators.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes that the single ampersand (`&`) is the standard logical AND operator used for combining boolean conditions in an `if` statement.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: In Java, standard logical AND used in conditional statements is `&&` (conditional AND), which implements short-circuiting. The single ampersand (`&`) is the bitwise AND operator, which, when applied to boolean types, performs a non-short-circuiting logical AND.
symptoms: A single '&' is used in an if condition.
The code segment is not part of the required grading logic, but shows a conceptual error in boolean expression construction.
misconceptions.root_cause: Confusion between bitwise operators and logical operators.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: For conditional statements (like `if` and `while`), always use `&&` for the logical AND operation to ensure standard short-circuiting behavior.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: High confidence. The single ampersand is explicitly used in the conditional example. Although this example is outside the main problem, it demonstrates a recurring conceptual error related to boolean logic.

evidence.note: The logical condition uses the bitwise AND operator '&' instead of the logical AND operator '&&'.

misconceptions.name: Complete task mismatch - solving wrong problem
misconceptions.description: The student submitted code for calculating distance between two points instead of a grade calculator. The entire solution addresses a different problem entirely.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to have submitted code from a different assignment or misunderstood the assignment requirement.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The submission should read a single numeric grade (0-100) and output the corresponding letter grade (A, B, C, D, or F) based on the specified ranges.
symptoms: Code reads x1, y1, x2, y2 coordinates instead of a grade
Code calculates Euclidean distance instead of mapping grades
No output of letter grades
Program logic is completely unrelated to the problem
misconceptions.root_cause: Student submitted the wrong file or completely misread the assignment requirements.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Start over with the correct problem. Read a single integer grade, then use if-else statements to check the ranges (90-100 for A, 80-89 for B, etc.) and print the corresponding letter.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Absolute certainty - the code solves an entirely different problem (distance calculation) with no attempt at grade conversion logic.

evidence.note: Code reads coordinates and calculates distance instead of reading a grade and converting it to a letter.
Class name indicates this is a distance calculation program, not a grade calculator.

misconceptions.task: Correct Boolean ranges for A and B
misconceptions.name: Use of single & instead of && operator
misconceptions.description: The student uses a single bitwise AND operator (&) instead of the logical AND operator (&&) in a conditional statement. While this appears in debug code, it demonstrates confusion about boolean operators.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes that & and && are interchangeable for boolean conditions, or may not understand the difference between bitwise and logical operators.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: In Java, && is the logical AND operator for boolean conditions. The & operator is a bitwise operator that performs bitwise AND on integers and can have unexpected behavior with booleans. For boolean logic, always use &&.
symptoms: Uses single & in boolean conditional: if (grade >= 80 & grade < 90)
misconceptions.root_cause: Confusion between bitwise operators and logical operators, or lack of familiarity with proper boolean logic syntax in Java.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Replace single & with && when combining boolean conditions. Remember: && is logical AND (short-circuits), & is bitwise AND (doesn't short-circuit and can behave unexpectedly with booleans).
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: High confidence - the code explicitly uses single & in a boolean context, which is clearly incorrect Java practice even though it may still evaluate correctly in this specific case.

evidence.note: Single & operator used instead of && for boolean condition combining.

related_concepts: Mapping problem statements to program structure
User input with Scanner for a single value
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The entire structure and prompts of the program clearly match a distance-between-points exercise, with no attempt to read or output a letter grade except for a small unrelated debug snippet.

The only grade-related code uses a hard-coded grade in a debug example and does not read input or output any letter grade, showing the required grade calculator was not implemented.

misconceptions.task: Correct Boolean ranges for A and B
misconceptions.name: Use of single '&' for conditional logic
misconceptions.description: The student uses the single ampersand operator (&) in a conditional statement, which performs a bitwise AND operation (even on boolean values), instead of the expected short-circuit logical AND operator (&&). While technically correct for boolean literals, it is stylistically incorrect, inefficient, and potentially dangerous if unintended side effects exist in the operands. This occurs in a separate debug section and does not affect the primary (wrong) program functionality.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes that '&' is the correct or equivalent operator for logical conjunction in conditional expressions in Java.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The logical AND operator (&&) should be used in conditional statements (if/while) as it guarantees short-circuit evaluation, improving performance and avoiding evaluation of the second operand if the first is false.
symptoms: Single ampersand used within an 'if' condition
misconceptions.root_cause: Confusion between bitwise operators (&, |) and logical operators (&&, ||).
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Replace the single '&' with the double '&&' for logical AND operations in conditions.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The single '&' is explicitly used in a test condition, indicating a potential misunderstanding of logical vs. bitwise operators in the context of boolean expressions, although it is self-contained in a debug section.

evidence.note: Single '&' is used for logical conjunction instead of '&&'.

misconceptions.task: Correct Boolean ranges for A and B
misconceptions.name: Bitwise AND used instead of Logical AND
misconceptions.description: The student uses a single ampersand (&) in a Boolean condition, which is the bitwise AND operator, rather than the logical AND operator (&&). This demonstrates confusion between bitwise operators and logical operators in conditional expressions.
misconceptions.student_belief: A single & can be used to combine Boolean conditions in an if statement
misconceptions.correct_understanding: In Java, && is the logical AND operator used for Boolean conditions, while & is the bitwise AND operator. For conditional logic, always use && or || for logical operations.
symptoms: Conditional statement uses & instead of &&
Bitwise operator applied to Boolean logic context
misconceptions.root_cause: Student may be confusing bitwise operators with logical operators, or transferred a pattern from another language
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Replace the single & with && in line 33. Change 'if (grade >= 80 & grade < 90)' to 'if (grade >= 80 && grade < 90)'
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Clear syntax evidence of single & in a Boolean condition context. Pattern is unambiguous.

evidence.note: Single ampersand (&) used instead of double ampersand (&&) for logical AND in conditional statement
